Then he met with President [[Nicos Anastasiades]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Après sa visite surprise sur le Charles-de-Gaulle, Hollande à Chypre|url=http://www.ouest-france.fr/politique/francois-hollande/apres-sa-visite-surprise-sur-le-charles-de-gaulle-hollande-chypre-3891428|language=fr|date=4 December 2015|publisher=[[Ouest France]]}}</ref> |- |{{Flag icon|Belgium}} [[Belgium]] |[[Brussels]] |{{sort|2015-11-17|17–18 December}} |President Hollande travelled to Brussels to attend a [[European Council]] regarding the [[United Kingdom European Union membership referendum]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://news.yahoo.com/eus-tusk-says-uk-reform-demands-unacceptable-001518552.html |title=EU warns Britain over summit demands |work=[[Yahoo! News]] |publisher=[[Yahoo!]] |agency=[[Agence France-Presse]] |last1=Kemp |first1=Danny |date=18 December 2015}}</ref> |}
== 2016 == [[File:Macri con Hollande1.jpg|thumb|President François Hollande with Argentine President [[Mauricio Macri]] at the [[Casa Rosada]] in [[Buenos Aires]], 24 February 2016]] In 2016, President François Hollande made 37 international trips to 30 different countries. The following were the international trips already made by President Hollande during the year: {| class="wikitable sortable outercollapse" style="margin: 1em auto 1em auto" |- ! width=120|Country ! width=100|Areas visited ! width=90|Date(s) ! width=550|Details |- |{{flag|India}} |[[Chandigarh]], [[Gurgaon]], [[New Delhi]] |24–26 January |On a state visit to India, President Hollande attended the [[Delhi Republic Day parade]], held along [[Rajpath]] in New Delhi, as the parade's honorary chief guest.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Arora|first1=Parthshri|title=French President Francois Hollande to be Chief Guest at Republic Day in India|url=http://indiatoday.intoday.in/story/french-president-francois-hollande-to-be-chief-guest-at-republic-day-in-india/1/548808.html|accessdate=27 December 2015|work=[[India Today]]|publisher=[[Living Media]]|date=16 December 2015}}</ref> He met with [[Prime Minister of India|Indian Prime Minister]] [[Narendra Modi]] to discuss bilateral cooperation in [[counter-terrorism]], [[nuclear power]] and [[sustainable development]]. The two leaders later signed a deal allowing India's purchase of 36 [[Dassault Rafale]] [[fighter aircraft]] from France.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Chatterjee|first1=Arunava|title=India-France sign deal for purchase of 36 Rafale jets|url=http://indiatoday.intoday.in/story/rafale-deal-talks-are-progressing-says-french-president-francois-hollande/1/578937.html|accessdate=22 February 2016|work=[[India Today]]|date=25 January 2016}}</ref> President Hollande and Prime Minister Modi also visited the [[Rock Garden of Chandigarh|Rock Garden]], the Capitol Complex, and the [[Government Museum and Art Gallery, Chandigarh|Government Museum and Art Gallery]] in Sector 10 in Chandigarh and inaugurated the Interim Secretariat of the International Solar Alliance, a [[solar energy]] initiative, at the [http://nise.res.in/ National Institute of Solar Energy] in Gurgaon.<ref>{{cite news|title=India, France united in fight against enemies of humanity: PM Modi|url=http://indianexpress.com/article/india/india-news-india/french-president-hollande-arrives-in-chandigarh-will-tour-city-with-pm-modi/|accessdate=22 February 2016|work=[[The Indian Express]]|date=26 January 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Modi, Hollande dedicate International Solar Alliance to the world|url=http://www.hindustantimes.com/india/modi-hollande-dedicate-international-solar-alliance-to-the-world/story-Tnuekmvwt4VBgzRfGEzxnO.html|accessdate=22 February 2016|work=[[Hindustan Times]]|date=26 January 2016}}</ref> |- |{{Flag icon|Belgium}} [[Belgium]] |[[Brussels]] |{{sort|2016-02-18|18–19 February}} |President Hollande travelled to Brussels to attend a [[European Council]] centered on the refugees crisis and on the conditions negotiated with UK before the [[United Kingdom European Union membership referendum]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-politics-eu-referendum-35599279|title=EU referendum: David Cameron 'battling for Britain' at summit|date=18 February 2016|work=BBC News}}</ref> |- |{{flag|Peru}} |[[Lima]] |23–24 February |President Hollande paid a state visit to Peru to meet with [[President of Peru|Peruvian President]] [[Ollanta Humala]], enhance bilateral trade, and promote investment opportunities for French businesses in the [[Economy of Peru|Peruvian economy]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Peru FM: Hollande's visit to set a privileged partnership with Peru|url=http://www.andina.com.pe/Ingles/noticia-peru-fm-hollandes-visit-to-set-a-privileged-partnership-with-peru-600143.aspx|accessdate=25 February 2016|agency=[[Andina (news agency)|Andina]]|date=23 February 2016}}</ref> The two leaders witnessed the signing of around 20 bilateral agreements on [[aerospace]], [[climate change]], [[counter-terrorism]], [[Defense (military)|defense]], and [[illegal drug trade]] and signed a joint declaration allowing for the establishment of a France–Peru [[privileged partnership]].<ref>{{cite news|title=French President Hollande visits Peru, in hope of boosting bilateral trade ties|url=http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2016-02/24/c_135124562.htm|accessdate=25 February 2016|agency=[[Xinhua News Agency]]|date=24 February 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=France President arrives in Peru|url=http://www.andina.com.pe/ingles/noticia-france-president-arrives-in-peru-600204.aspx|accessdate=25 February 2016|agency=[[Andina (news agency)|Andina]]|date=23 February 2016}}</ref> |- |{{flag|Argentina}} |[[Buenos Aires]] |24–25 February |Upon congratulating [[President of Argentina|Argentine President]] [[Mauricio Macri]] on his victory in the [[Argentine general election, 2015|2015 elections]], President Hollande announced that he will visit Argentina in February to meet with him.<ref>{{cite news|title=François Hollande felicitó a Macri por su triunfo y confirmó que vendrá al país en febrero|url=http://www.lanacion.com.ar/1849879-hollande-felicito-a-macri-por-su-triunfo-y-confirmo-que-vendra-al-pais-en-febrero|accessdate=29 November 2015|work=La Nacion|date=29 November 2015|language=Spanish}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Mauricio Macri recibe al presidente François Hollande en Casa Rosada|url=http://www.lanacion.com.ar/1873938-el-presidente-frances-franzois-hollande-llego-a-la-argentina|accessdate=24 February 2016|work=La Nacion|date=24 February 2016|language=Spanish}}</ref>
During their meeting at [[Casa Rosada]] in Buenos Aires, the two presidents discussed the [[Refugees of the Syrian Civil War|Syrian refugee crisis]], with Hollande suggesting to Macri that Argentina could assist in dealing with the crisis after commending the country's history with [[Lebanese Argentines|Lebanese]] and [[Syrian Argentines|Syrian immigration]].<ref>{{cite news|title=During an official visit in Argentina, French President Francois Hollande suggests that the South American country could help with the Syrian refugee crisis|url=http://www.dailyjournal.net/view/story/d35aa7ea62e9455a814facd69a5f458f/LT--Argentina-French-President|accessdate=25 February 2016|work=Daily Journal|agency=[[Associated Press]]|date=24 February 2016}}</ref> Hollande also paid tribute to the [[Mothers of the Plaza de Mayo]], whose children [[Forced disappearance#Argentina|disappeared]] during Argentina's [[Dirty War]] between the late 1970s and early 80s, by throwing flowers onto the [[Río de la Plata]], where he was joined by the [[Grandmothers of the Plaza de Mayo]], the organization aimed to find the missing children, and mentioned France's victimization to [[National Reorganization Process|Argentina's military dictatorship]] when "22" of the victims were French.<ref>{{cite news|title=Hollande at ESMA memorial: France aware mass crime committed in Argentina|url=http://www.buenosairesherald.com/article/209493/hollande-at-esma-memorial-france-aware-mass-crime-committed-in-argentina-|accessdate=25 February 2016|work=[[Buenos Aires Herald]]|date=25 February 2016}}</ref> As a fan of [[Association football|football]], he later toured the [[La Bombonera]] stadium with President Macri (a former [[List of Boca Juniors chairmen|chairman]] of [[Boca Juniors]]) and former footballers [[David Trezeguet]] and [[Omar da Fonseca]].<ref>{{cite news|title=François Hollande inscrit un penalty en Argentine|url=http://sport24.lefigaro.fr/le-scan-sport/buzz/2016/02/26/27002-20160226ARTFIG00152-francois-hollande-inscrit-un-penalty-en-argentine.php|accessdate=27 February 2016|work=[[Le Figaro]]|date=26 February 2016|language=French}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=François Hollande marque un péno dans la mythique Bombonera (mais sans gardien)|url=http://www.20minutes.fr/sport/1794507-20160225-francois-hollande-marque-peno-mythique-bombonera-gardien|accessdate=27 February 2016|work=[[20 minutes (France)|20 minutes]]|agency=[[Agence to pick up ‘World Statesman Award’ in New York|accessdate=20 September 2016|work=[[France 24]]}}</ref> |- |{{flag|Germany}} |[[Berlin]] |{{sort|2016-09-28|28 September}} |In Berlin, President Hollande met some European industrial leaders members of the [[European Round Table of Industrialists]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Merkel to meet Hollande, Juncker in bid to promote competition in EU|url=http://en.europeonline-magazine.eu/merkel-to-meet-hollande-juncker-in-bid-to-promote-competition-in-eu_486735.html|publisher=Europe Online|date=28 September 2016}}</ref> |- |{{flag|Israel}} |[[Jerusalem]] |{{sort|2016-09-30|30 September}} |President Hollande attended the funeral of former [[Israeli President]] [[Shimon Peres]].<ref>{{cite news|title=World leaders to attend funeral for Israel's Shimon Peres|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-middle-east-37498086|accessdate=29 September 2016|work=[[BBC News]]|date=28 September 2016}}</ref> |- |{{flag|Germany}} |[[Berlin]] |{{sort|2016-10-19|19–20 October}} |President Hollande attended a summit on [[Ukraine]] conflict hosted by [[Chancellor of Germany|German Chancellor]] [[Angela Merkel]] along with [[President of Russia|Russian President]] [[Vladimir Putin]] and [[President of Ukraine|Ukrainian President]] [[Petro Poroshenko]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Summit On Ukraine Conflict Begins In Berlin|url=http://www.rferl.org/a/russia-ukraine-merkel-putin-poroshenko-hollande-berlin-summit/28063677.html|publisher=Radio Free Europe|date=19 October 2016}}</ref> |- |{{Flag|Belgium}} |[[Brussels]] |{{sort|2016-10-20|20–21 October}} |President Hollande travelled to Brussels to attend a [[European Council]]. |- |{{Flag|Morocco}} |[[Marrakech]] |{{sort|2016-11-15|15–16 November}} |President Hollande attended the [[2016 United Nations Climate Change Conference]]. |- |{{flagicon|Germany}} [[Germany]] |[[Berlin]] |{{sort|2016-11-18|18 November}} |President Hollande traveled Berlin for the meeting with other European leaders of the "[[NATO Quint|Quint]]": [[German Chancellor]] [[Angela Merkel]], [[British Prime Minister]] [[Theresa May]] [[Italian Prime Minister]] [[Matteo Renzi]], and [[Spanish Prime Minister]] [[Mariano Rajoy]], as well as the [[President of the United States]] [[Barack Obama]] in the final such meeting of his presidency. The leaders discussed trade, the [[Ukrainian crisis]], the [[Syrian Civil War]], and [[Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant]].<ref>{{cite web|author1=[[Ben Rhodes (White House staffer)|Rhodes, Ben]]|title=The President Abroad: A Look Ahead at Greece, Germany, and Peru|url=https://medium.com/the-white-house/the-president-abroad-a-look-ahead-at-greece-germany-and-peru-265b9c00a94e#.k789x9vn7|website=[[Medium (website)|Medium]]|publisher=A Medium Corporation|accessdate=November 16, 2016}}</ref> |- |{{Flag|Madagascar}} |[[Antananarivo]] |{{sort|2016-11-26|26–27 November}} |President Hollande travelled to Antananarivo to attend the [[Organisation internationale de la Francophonie#Summits|Francophonie Summit]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Dossiers chauds, absences: ce qu'il faut savoir sur le sommet de la Francophonie|url=http://www.rfi.fr/afrique/20161126-dossiers-chauds-absences-faut-savoir-sommet-francophonie-oif-madagascar|publisher=[[Radio France Internationale]]|language=fr|date=26 November 2016}}</ref> |- |{{flag|Czech Republic}} |[[Prague]] |{{sort|2016-11-30|30 November}} |President Hollande travelled to Prague for a work visit during which he met the President and Prime Minister as well as the French community. |- |{{flag|United Arab Emirates}} |[[Abu Dhabi]] |{{sort|2016-12-02|2–3 December}} |President Hollande travelled to Abu Dhabi during the [[National Day (United Arab Emirates)|National Day]], before visiting the site of the [[Louvre Abu Dhabi]] and the [[Abu Dhabi base]]. |- |{{flag|Germany}} |[[Berlin]] |{{sort|2016-12-13|13 December}} |President Hollande travelled to Berlin to meet with Chancellor [[Angela Merkel]]. |- |{{Flag|Belgium}} |[[Brussels]] |{{sort|2016-12-15|15 December}} |President Hollande travelled to Brussels to attend a [[European Council]]. |}
==2017== In 2017, President François Hollande made thirteen international trips to thirteen different countries. The following are the trips made by President Hollande in 2017: {| class="wikitable sortable outercollapse" style="margin: 1em auto 1em auto" |- ! width=120|Country ! width=100|Areas visited ! width=90|Date(s) ! width=550|Details |- | {{flag|Iraq}} | [[Baghdad]], [[Erbil]] | {{sort|2017-01-02|2 January}} | {{further|Opération Chammal}} President Hollande travelled to Iraq to reiterate France's support for the [[American-led intervention in Iraq (2014–present)|American-led intervention in Iraq]] supported by the [[Iraqi government]] against ISIL. He travelled to Baghdad to meet with [[President of Iraq|Iraqi President]] [[Fuad Masum]] and [[Prime Minister of Iraq|Prime Minister]] [[Haider al-Abadi]], and to Erbil to meet with [[President of Iraqi Kurdistan|Iraqi Kurdistan President]] [[Masoud Barzani]] as well as French forces stationed in the area.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Mostafa|first1=Mohamed|title=Hollande arrives in Baghdad to reiterate support for Iraq against IS|url=http://www.iraqinews.com/features/hollande-arrives-baghdad-reiterate-support-iraq/|accessdate=2 January 2017|work=IraqiNews.com|date=2 January 2017}}</ref> Hollande said that France's involvement in the intervention against ISIL "prevents acts of [[terrorism in France]]."<ref>{{cite news|title=Francois Hollande: Fighting IS in Iraq prevents terrorism in France|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-middle-east-38487529|accessdate=2 January 2017|publisher=[[BBC News]]|date=2 January 2017}}</ref> |- | {{flag|Mali}} | [[Gao]], [[Bamako]] | {{sort|2017-01-13|13–14 January}} | President Hollande travelled to Bamako for the 27th Africa–France Summit. On his way to Bamako, he stopped at the military base of Gao to visit French forces engaged in [[Operation Barkhane]]. He attended a state dinner offered by the President of Mali [[Ibrahim Boubacar Keïta]]. |- | {{flag|Chile}} | [[Santiago]], [[Antofagasta]] | {{sort|2017-01-21|21–22 January}} | President Hollande paid an official visit to Chile. He met the [[President of Chile]] [[Michelle Bachelet]] and launched the Franco-Chilean year of Innovation before visiting the Bolero photovoltaic park.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.t13.cl/noticia/mundo/hollande-abre-chile-su-ultima-gira-america-latina|title=Hollande abre en Chile su última gira por América Latina|date=21 January 2017|language=es}}</ref> |- | {{flag|Colombia}} | [[Bogotá]], [[Cali]], [[Caldono, Cauca|Caldono]] | {{sort|2017-01-22|22–24 January}} | President Hollande paid an official visit to Colombia including an hommage to [[Simon Bolivar]] and a day around the [[Colombian peace process]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.europe1.fr/politique/francois-hollande-en-colombie-pour-une-visite-de-deux-jours-2957953|title=François Hollande en Colombie pour une visite de deux jours|date=23 January 2017|language=fr|publisher=[[Europe 1]]}}</ref> |- | {{Flag|Germany}} | [[Berlin]] | {{sort|2017-01-27|27 January}} | President Hollande met with [[Chancellor of Germany|German Chancellor]] [[Angela Merkel]] in Berlin to defend free-trade.<ref>{{cite news|title=Nouvelle donne économique : quelle place pour l'Europe ?|url=http://www.francetvinfo.fr/politique/francois-hollande/nouvelle-donne-economique-quelle-place-pour-l-europe_2039265.html|accessdate=27 January 2017|publisher=Francetvinfo|date=27 January 2017}}</ref> |- |{{flag|Portugal}} |[[Lisbon]] |{{sort|2017-01-28|28 January}} |President Hollande travelled to Lisbon to attend the second Mediterranean EU countries’ Summit.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.themalaymailonline.com/money/article/brexit-and-trump-top-southern-eu-nations-summit|title=Brexit and Trump top southern EU nations summit|date=28 January 2017|publisher=The Malay Mail Online}}</ref> |- |{{flag|Malta}} |[[Valletta]] |{{sort|2017-02-03|3 February}} |President Hollande travelled to Malta to attend an informal EU summit. |- |{{flag|Spain}} |[[Malaga]] |{{sort|2017-02-20|20 February}} |President Hollande travelled to Malaga for a Spain-France summit.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.theolivepress.es/spain-news/2017/02/20/spain-pm-rajoy-french-president-hollande-malaga-important-summit/|title=Spain PM Rajoy and French president Hollande in Malaga for political summit|date=20 February 2017|publisher=The Olive Press}}</ref> |- |{{Flag|Belgium}} |[[Brussels]] |{{sort|2017-03-09|9–10 March}} |President Hollande travelled to Brussels to attend a [[European Council]]. |- |{{Flag|Italy}} |[[Rome]] |{{sort|2017-03-25|25 March}} |President Hollande travelled to Rome for the 60th anniversary of the [[Treaty of Rome]]. |- |{{Flag|Singapore}} |[[Singapore]] |{{sort|2017-03-26|26-27 March}} |President Hollande was the first French president to visit Singapore. |- |{{Flag|Malaysia}} |[[Kuala Lumpur]] |{{sort|2017-03-27|27-29 March}} |President Hollande travelled for a State visit. |- |{{Flag|Indonesia}} |[[Jakarta]] |{{sort|2017-03-29|29 March}} |President Hollande travelled for a State visit. |- |{{flag|Spain}} |[[Madrid]] |{{sort|2017-04-10|10 April}} |President Hollande travelled to Madrid for a Mediterranean EU countries’ Summit. |- |{{flag|Belgium}} |[[Brussels]] |{{sort|2017-04-29|29 April}} |President Hollande travelled to Brussels to attend an extraordinary [[European Council]] on [[Brexit]]. |- |{{flag|Germany}} |[[Berlin]] |{{sort|2017-05-08|8 May}} |President Hollande travelled to Berlin to meet with [[German Chancellor]] [[Angela Merkel]] for a bilateral meeting and a private dinner following the [[French presidential election, 2017|French presidential election]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Hollande to meet Merkel after French election|url=http://www.business-standard.com/article/news-ians/hollande-to-meet-merkel-after-french-election-117050700014_1.html|accessdate=8 May 2017|agency=[[Indo-Asian News Service]]|via=''[[Business Standard]]''|date=7 May 2017}}</ref> It was his last presidential trip. |}

page.title: List of reportedly haunted locations in South Africa

revision.comment: added [[Category:Lists of reportedly haunted locations]] using [[WP:HC|HotCat]]
revision.text: [[File:Castle of GH 1.jpg|thumb|200px|[[Castle of Good Hope]]]] [[File:Erasmus kasteel (2).JPG|thumb|200px|[[Erasmus Castle]]]] The following is a list of reportedly haunted locations in South Africa. ==Haunted locations== *'''[[Castle of Good Hope]]''': This 17th-century [[Dutch East India Company]] fort in [[Cape Town]] is believed to be the most haunted site in [[South Africa]]. The resident ghosts reportedly include the ghost of [[Lady Anne Barnard]] who lived there, the ghost of a soldier who hanged himself in the bell tower and the ghosts of soldiers pacing the [[battlement]]s.{{cite book|last1=Hopkins|first1=Pat|title=Ghosts of South Africa|date=2006|publisher=Zebra Press|location=Cape Town|isbn=9781770073036|url=https://books.google.co.za/books?id=qVA6zfB-LCUC|accessdate=17 June 2014}}{{rp|18–28}}{{cite news|last1=Peters |first1=Melanie |title=Ghosts haunt guards at Cape Town Castle |url=http://www.iol.co.za/news/south-africa/ghosts-haunt-guards-at-cape-town-castle-1.63293#.U59SEJSSyyg |accessdate=16 June 2014 |work=IOL |date=30 March 2001 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6QNjBjv0F?url=http://www.iol.co.za/news/south-africa/ghosts-haunt-guards-at-cape-town-castle-1.63293 |archivedate=16 June 2014 |deadurl=no |df= }}{{cite news|last1=Jackman |first1=Rebecca |title=Inside SA's most haunted site |url=http://www.iol.co.za/travel/south-africa/western-cape/inside-sa-s-most-haunted-site-1.1550960#.U59OnZSSyyg |accessdate=16 June 2014 |work=Weekend Argus |date=23 July 2013 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6QNiswNKy?url=http://www.iol.co.za/travel/south-africa/western-cape/inside-sa-s-most-haunted-site-1.1550960 |archivedate=16 June 2014 |deadurl=no |df= }} *'''[[Erasmus Castle]]/Kasteel''': "Die Spookhuis" or Erasmus Castle in [[Erasmuskloof, Pretoria]], local residents often report strange noises and ghost sightings in and around the Victorian mansion. Paranormal activity includes lit windows in the uninhabited mansion, and hearing people moaning at night.{{cite web|url=http://boksburghistorical.com/index_files/BHAaug2004.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2015-09-26 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304120538/http://boksburghistorical.com/index_files/BHAaug2004.pdf |archivedate=2016-03-04 |df= }} * '''[[Fort Frederick, Eastern Cape|Fort Frederick]]''': In [[Eastern Cape]], is a fort built by the British during 1799 in Algoa Bay that is reportedly haunted by theatrical ghosts of a Shakespearian play.{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com.au/books?id=qVA6zfB-LCUC&pg=PA170&lpg=PA170&dq=fort+frederick+rsa&source=bl&ots=-juAEkyq5i&sig=NcTcDN5-9sWis3g2HohsgLcAV60&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CEMQ6AEwB2oVChMIquuP9J-fyAIVSpeUCh1eNgLr#v=onepage&q=fort%20frederick%20rsa&f=false|title=Ghosts of South Africa|publisher=}} *'''Foxwood House''' in [[Johannesburg]]. Paranormal activity includes mysterious footsteps and visitors seeing an anonymous spectral woman with an anonymous child on the balcony of this building.{{cite web|url=http://www.getaway.co.za/travel-ideas/places-to.../south-africas-haunted-hotels/|title=7 of South Africa's best haunted hotels - Getaway Magazine|work=Getaway Magazine}} *'''Kempton Park Hospital''': This abandoned hospital in [[Kempton Park, Gauteng]] is frequented by thrill-seekers and [[Ghost hunting|ghost hunters]].{{cite news|last1=Theresa |first1=Taylor |title=Ghosts that haunt the old hospital |url=http://www.iol.co.za/news/south-africa/gauteng/ghosts-that-haunt-the-old-hospital-1.1084828#.U59cfJSSyyg |accessdate=16 June 2014 |work=The Star |date=17 June 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6QNmEDm4C?url=http://www.iol.co.za/news/south-africa/gauteng/ghosts-that-haunt-the-old-hospital-1.1084828 |archivedate=16 June 2014 |deadurl=no |df= }}{{cite news|last1=Bester|first1=Zianko|title=Something strange in your neighbourhood? Call Gauteng Paranormal Society|url=http://www.thenewage.co.za/mobi/Detail.aspx?NewsID=60172&CatID=12|accessdate=18 June 2014|work=The New Age|date=24 August 2012|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140618150105/http://www.thenewage.co.za/mobi/Detail.aspx?NewsID=60172&CatID=12|archivedate=18 June 2014|deadurl=no}} *'''Nottingham Road Hotel''': A hotel in [[KwaZulu-Natal]], where the ghost of a former barmaid is said to still wander the hotel moving pots, light fixtures, and sheets, as well as ringing the service bell.{{rp|174–175}}[http://www.articlesphere.com/Article/Scary-Creatures-of-the-Night--Scariest-Hotels-in-the-World/165029 Nottingham Road Hotel] from Articlesphere.com * '''[[Old Presidency]]''': In [[Bloemfontein]], was the official residence of the former [[Orange Free State]]. The stables at the back of the building are thought to be haunted with several reports of people hearing carriages moving into the stables. The premises reportedly house the ghost of a dog with many people hearing ephemeral barking at night. There are also many stories of children being spotted within the building due to the buildings tenure as a school and hostel.{{cite web|url=http://www.joemynhardt.com/blog/the-haunting-of-the-old-presidency-ou-presidensie-|title=The Haunting of the Old Presidency (Ou Presidensie)|publisher=}} *'''[[Somerset Hospital (Cape Town)|Somerset Hospital]]''': South Africa's oldest hospital in [[Green Point, Cape Town]], where resident ghosts reportedly include Sister [[Henrietta Stockdale]], a blonde girl combing her hair and others that roam the corridors at night.{{rp|157}}{{cite news|last1=Lovell |first1=Jeremy |title=Cape Town markets its ghostly history |url=http://www.iol.co.za/news/south-africa/cape-town-markets-its-ghostly-history-1.55734#.U6BATpSSyyg |accessdate=17 June 2014 |date=10 December 2000 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6QOnxygGr?url=http://www.iol.co.za/news/south-africa/cape-town-markets-its-ghostly-history-1.55734 |archivedate=17 June 2014 |deadurl=no |df= }} ==See also== *[[List of reportedly haunted locations]] ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Ghosts|state=expanded}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Haunted locations in the world}} [[Category:Geography-related lists]] [[Category:Lists of reportedly haunted locations]]

revision.text:
This is a '''list of warehouse districts''' that are notable.
A '''warehouse district''' or '''warehouse row''' is an area found in many urban setting known for being the current or former location of numerous [[warehouses]]. Logistically, warehouses are often located in [[industrial park]]s, with access to bulk transportation outlets such as highways, railroads, and airports.<ref>G. Jason Goddard, Bill Marcum, ''Real Estate Investment: A Value Based Approach'' (2012), p. 208.</ref> The areas where warehouses are typically built are often designated as [[Zoning|special zones]] for [[urban planning]] purposes, and "can have their own substantial [[infrastructure]]s, comprising [[road]]s, [[Public utility|utilities]], and [[Energy industry|energy systems]]".<ref>Neil S. Grigg, ''Economics and Finance for Engineers and Planners'' (2009), p. 39.</ref> In many instances, where changing social and economic conditions have made it unfeasable to maintain an existing warehouse district, cities or communities will invest in converting the district to other purposes for which this infrastructure can still be used, such an art district.<ref>American Planning Association, ''Planning and Urban Design Standards'' (2006), p. 435.</ref> Such a converted area may continue to be known as a warehouse district.
Notable areas known as warehouse districts include:
==Canada== * [[Distillery District]] is located in [[Toronto]], [[Ontario]] and is the largest collection of [[Victorian-era]] industrial architecture in North America.
==Germany== * ''[[Speicherstadt]]'' in Hamburg, Germany
==United Kingdom== *[[Harringay Warehouse District]]
==United States (by state then city)== ===Arizona=== *[[Tucson Warehouse Historic District]], Tucson, [[National Register of Historic Places listings in Pima County, Arizona|listed on the NRHP in Pima County]]
===Arkansas=== *[[Hot Springs Railroad Warehouse Historic District]], Hot Springs, [[National Register of Historic Places listings in Garland County, Arkansas|listed on the NRHP in Garland County]]
===California=== *[[Warehouse Row (Fresno, California)|Warehouse Row]] Fresno, [[National Register of Historic Places listings in Fresno County, California|listed on the NRHP in Fresno County]] *[[Wholesale District, Los Angeles|Warehouse District]], Los Angeles *[[Oakland Waterfront Warehouse District]], Oakland, [[National Register of Historic Places listings in Alameda County, California|listed on the NRHP in Alameda County]]
===Georgia=== *[[Athens Warehouse Historic District]], Athens, [[National Register of Historic Places listings in Clarke County, Georgia|listed on the NRHP in Clarke County]] *[[East Vine Street Warehouse and Depot District]], Statesboro, [[National Register of Historic Places listings in Bulloch County, Georgia|listed on the NRHP in Bulloch County]]
===Idaho=== *[[Pocatello Warehouse Historic District]], Pocatello, [[National Register of Historic Places listings in Bannock County, Idaho|listed on the NRHP in Bannock County]] *[[Twin Falls Warehouse Historic District]], Twin Falls, [[National Register of Historic Places listings in Twin Falls County, Idaho|listed on the NRHP in Twin Falls County]]
===Illinois=== * [[Fulton River District, Chicago|Fulton River District]], Chicago * Warehouse Historic District, Peoria, [[National Register of Historic Places listings in Peoria County, Illinois|listed on the NRHP in Peoria County, Illinois]]
===Iowa=== *[[Crescent Warehouse Historic District]], Davenport, [[National Register of Historic Places listings in east Davenport, Iowa|listed on the NRHP in Scott County]]
===Kansas=== *[[Wichita Historic Warehouse and Jobbers District]], Wichita, [[National Register of Historic Places listings in Sedgwick County, Kansas|listed on the NRHP in Sedgwick County]]
===Kentucky=== *[[Warehouse District (Danville, Kentucky)|Warehouse District]], Danville, [[National Register of Historic Places listings in Boyle County, Kentucky|listed on the National Register of Historic Places in Boyle County]] *[[Hopkinsville Warehouse Historic District]], Hopkinsville, [[National Register of Historic Places listings in Christian County, Kentucky|listed on the NRHP in Christian County]]
===Louisiana=== * [[New Orleans Central Business District]], New Orleans
===Michigan=== *[[River Place (Detroit, Michigan)|River Place]], [[Detroit]], [[National Register of Historic Places listings in Detroit, Michigan|listed on the NRHP in Wayne County]]
===Minnesota=== *[[Minneapolis Warehouse Historic District]], Minneapolis, Minnesota, [[National Register of Historic Places listings in Hennepin County, Minnesota|listed on the NRHP in Hennepin County]] *[[North Loop, Minneapolis|North Loop]], Minneapolis, which includes the ''Minneapolis Warehouse Historic District''
===Missouri=== *[[Warehouse Row Historic District]], Cape Girardeau, [[National Register of Historic Places listings in Cape Girardeau County, Missouri|listed on the NRHP in Cape Girardeau County]] *[[Walnut Street Warehouse and Commercial Historic District]], Kansas City, [[National Register of Historic Places listings in Jackson County, Missouri|listed on the NRHP in Jackson County]] *[[Cupples Warehouse District]], St. Louis, [[National Register of Historic Places listings in St. Louis (city, A–L)|listed on the NRHP in St. Louis, Missouri]] * [[Washington Avenue Loft District]], St. Louis *[[Springfield Warehouse and Industrial Historic District]], Springfield, [[National Register of Historic Places listings in Greene County, Missouri|listed on the NRHP in Greene County]]
===New York=== *[[Meatpacking District]], New York
===North Carolina=== *[[Greenville Tobacco Warehouse Historic District]], Greenville, [[National Register of Historic Places listings in Pitt County, North Carolina|listed on the NRHP in Pitt County]] *[[Wilson Central Business-Tobacco Warehouse Historic District]], Wilson, [[National Register of Historic Places listings in Wilson County, North Carolina|listed on the NRHP in Wilson County]]
===Ohio=== *[[Cincinnati East Manufacturing and Warehouse District]], Cincinnati, listed on the NRHP *[[Cleveland Warehouse District]], Cleveland, listed on the NRHP in Cleveland, Ohio *[[Huron-Superior Streets Warehouse-Produce Historic District]], Toledo, [[National Register of Historic Places listings in Lucas County, Ohio|listed on the NRHP in Lucas County]]
===Pennsylvania=== *[[Strip District]], Pittsburgh
===South Carolina=== *[[Waccamaw River Warehouse Historic District]], Conway, [[National Register of Historic Places listings in Horry County, South Carolina|listed on the NRHP in Horry County]]
===South Dakota=== *[[Old Courthouse and Warehouse Historic District]], Sioux Falls, [[National Register of Historic Places listings in Minnehaha County, South Dakota|listed on the NRHP in Minnehaha County]]
===Tennessee=== *[[Market Street Warehouse Historic District]], Chattanooga, [[National Register of Historic Places listings in Hamilton County, Tennessee|listed on the NRHP in Hamilton County]] *[[Johnson City Warehouse and Commerce Historic District]], Johnson City, [[National Register of Historic Places listings in Washington County, Tennessee|listed on the NRHP in Washington County]] *[[Jackson Avenue Warehouse District]], Knoxville, listed on the NRHP in Knox County *[[Southern Terminal and Warehouse Historic District]], Knoxville, [[National Register of Historic Places listings in Knox County, Tennessee|listed on the NRHP in Knox County]] *[[South Bluffs Warehouse Historic District]], Memphis, [[National Register of Historic Places listings in Shelby County, Tennessee|listed on the NRHP in Shelby County]]
===Texas=== * [[EaDo, Houston|EaDo]], [[Houston]] * [[Warehouse District (Austin, Texas)|Warehouse District]], [[Austin, Texas|Austin]] * [[West End Historic District, Dallas, Texas]], Dallas
===Utah=== *[[Warehouse District (Salt Lake City, Utah)|Warehouse District]], Salt Lake City, [[National Register of Historic Places listings in Salt Lake County, Utah|listed on the National Register of Historic Places in Salt Lake County]]
===Virginia=== *[[Danville Tobacco Warehouse and Residential District]], Danville, [[National Register of Historic Places listings in Danville, Virginia|listed on the NRHP in Danville]] *[[Roanoke Warehouse Historic District]], Roanoke, [[National Register of Historic Places listings in Roanoke, Virginia|listed on the NRHP in Roanoke]]
===Washington=== *[[Desmet Avenue Warehouse Historic District]], Spokane, [[National Register of Historic Places listings in Spokane County, Washington|listed on the NRHP in Spokane County]] *[[Union Depot-Warehouse Historic District]], Tacoma, [[National Register of Historic Places listings in Pierce County, Washington|listed on the NRHP in Pierce County]]
===West Virginia=== *[[Morgantown Wharf and Warehouse Historic District]], Morgantown, [[National Register of Historic Places listings in Monongalia County, West Virginia|listed on the NRHP in Monongalia County]] *[[Wheeling Warehouse Historic District]], Wheeling, [[National Register of Historic Places listings in Ohio County, West Virginia|listed on the NRHP in Ohio County]]
===Wisconsin=== *[[Historic Third Ward, Milwaukee]], Milwaukee
==References== {{reflist}}
==See also== * [[Arts district]] * [[Loft apartment]]
{{Developments}}

{{For|the Massey Medal in Architecture, named in honour of [[Vincent Massey]]|Governor General's Award}} The [[Royal Canadian Geographical Society]] (RCGS) awards the '''Massey Medal''' annually to recognize outstanding personal achievement in the exploration, development or description of the [[geography]] of [[Canada]]. The award was established in 1959, by the [[Massey Foundation]], named for industrialist [[Hart Massey]]. ==Recipients==
*2017 - David Morrison *2016 - Steve Blasco *2015 - Brian Osborne *2014 - Derald Smith *2013 - [[David Ley]] *2012 - Graeme Wynn *2011 - David Livingstone *2010 - [[Raymond A. Price]] *2009 - [[Michael Church (geographer)|Michael Church]] *2008 - [[Bruce Mitchell (geographer)|Bruce Mitchell]] *2007 - [[Eddy Carmack]] *2006 - [[Serge Courville]] *2005 - [[Timothy R. Oke|Tim Oke]] *2004 - [[Larry Bourne]] *2003 - [[Cole Harris|Richard Colebrook Harris]] *2002 - [[John Oliver Wheeler]] *2001 - [[Lawrence McCann]] *2000 - [[Robert John McGhee|Robert McGhee]] *1999 - [[Alexander T. Davidson]] *1998 - [[William C. Wonders]] *1997 - [[James Archibald Houston]] *1996 - [[James P. Bruce]] *1995 - [[Pierre Camu]] *1994 - [[Henri Dorion]] *1993 - [[J. Gordon Nelson]] *1992 - [[Stewart Dixon MacDonald]] *1991 - [[George D. Hobson]] *1990 - [[Byron Boville]] *1989 - [[John D. Mollard]]
*1988 - [[John Warkentin]] *1987 - [[Charles Richard Harington]] *1986 - [[David McCurdy Baird]] *1985 - [[Morley K. Thomas]] *1984 - Captain [[Thomas Charles Pullen]] *1983 - [[Willis F. Roberts]] *1982 - [[Trevor Lloyd (geographer)|Trevor Lloyd]] *1981 - [[Raymond Thorsteinsson]] *1980 - [[Maurice Hall Haycock]] *1979 - [[Ernest Frederick Roots]] *1978 - [[Edward Gustav Pleva]] *1977 - [[Thomas Henry Manning]] *1976 - [[Louis-Edmond Hamelin]] *1975 - [[William M. Gilchrist]] *1974 - [[Kenneth Hare|Frederick Kenneth Hare]] *1973 - [[Pierre Dansereau]] *1972 - [[Isobel Moira Dunbar]] *1971 - [[John Lewis Robinson]] *1970 - [[Murray Edmund Watts]] *1969 - [[Donald Fulton Putnam]] *1968 - [[Colonel Cyril Horace Smith]] *1967 - [[J. Ross Mackay]] *1966 - [[Erling Porsild|Alf Erling Porsild]] *1965 - [[Hugh Samuel Bostock]] *1964 - [[Yves Fortier (geologist)|Yves Oscar Fortier]] *1963 - [[Graham Westbrook Rowley]] *1962 - [[Diamond Jenness]] *1961 - [[Owen Connor Struan Robertson]] *1960 - [[Keith Rogers Greenaway]] *1959 - [[Henry Asbjorn Larsen]]
{{Clear}} ==External links== *[http://www.rcgs.org/awards/massey_medal/previous_winners.asp Massey Medal Award Recipients] [[Category:Geography awards]] [[Category:Canadian science and technology awards]] [[Category:Awards established in 1959]] [[Category:Royal Canadian Geographical Society]]

revision.comment: Reverted 2 edits by [[Special:Contributions/122.62.19.91|122.62.19.91]] ([[User talk:122.62.19.91|talk]]) to last revision by InternetArchiveBot. ([[WP:TW|TW]])
revision.text:
'''Navigational instruments''' refers to the instruments used by nautical navigators and pilots as tools of their trade. The purpose of navigation is to ascertain the present position and to determine the speed, direction etc. to arrive at the port or point of destination.
==Charts and drafting instruments== *'''[[Nautical chart|Charts]]''' are maps of the areas to be navigated with details specific to the marine environment. *'''Computing aids''': used in the necessary mathematical calculations. Today electronic [[computers]] or [[calculators]] are used. Other traditional aids used included tables (trigonometric, logarithms, etc.) and [[slide rules]]. *'''[[Caliper#Divider caliper|Dividers]]''' used for measuring lengths of lines and approximate lengths of non-linear paths on a chart. *'''[[Nautical almanac]]''' used to determine the position in the sky of a celestial body after a sight has been taken. *'''[[Parallel rulers|Parallel rules]]''' used for transferring a line to a parallel position. Also used to compare the orientation of a line to a magnetic or geographic orientation on a [[compass rose]].
==Direct measuring== *'''[[Chip log]] and [[hourglass|sand glass]]''' serve to measure the ship's speed through the water. *'''[[Sounding line]]''' used to measure the depth of the water and to pick up samples from the bottom.
==Position finding instruments==
===Celestial navigation instruments===
These instruments are used primarily to measure the elevation or altitude of a [[celestial object]]:
*'''[[Back staff]]''', the best known of which is the Davis' quadrant. It could measure the altitude of the sun without having the navigator directly observe the sun. *'''[[Cross staff]]''', an older instrument long out of use. *'''[[Kamal (navigation)|Kamal]]''' Very simple instrument used primarily by Arabian navigators. It consists of a small board with a knotted piece of twine through the center. The observer holds one of the knots in his mouth and extends the board away so that the edges make a constant angle with his eyes. *'''[[Mariner's astrolabe]]''' Derived from the [[astrolabe]], it was developed in late 15th century and found use in the 16th to 17th centuries. It was replaced by the [[back staff]] and later by the [[octant (instrument)|octant]] and [[sextant]]. *'''[[Quadrant (instrument)|Quadrant]]''' A very simple instrument which used a plumb bob.
These instruments are also used to measure the angular distance between objects:
*'''[[Octant (instrument)|Octant]]''', invented in 1731. The first widely accepted instrument that could measure an angle without being strongly affected by movement. *'''[[Sextant]]''', derived from the octant in 1757, eventually made all previous instruments used for the same purpose obsolete.
===Bearing instruments=== *'''[[Pelorus (instrument)|Pelorus]]''' used to determine bearings relative to the ship's heading of landmarks, other ships, etc.
===Compasses=== *'''[[Bearing compass]]''' used to determine magnetic bearings of landmarks, other ships or celestial bodies. *'''[[Magnetic compass]]''' used to determine the magnetic heading of the ship.
===Timekeeping=== *'''[[Marine chronometer]]''' used to determine time at the [[prime meridian]] with great precision which is necessary when reducing sights in celestial navigation. *'''[[Nocturnal (instrument)|Nocturnal]]''' used to determine apparent local time by viewing the [[Polaris]] and its surrounding stars. *'''[[Sundial#Ring dials|Ring dial]]''' or '''astronomical ring''' used to measure the height of a celestial body above the horizon. It could be used to find the altitude of the sun or determine local time. It let sunlight shine through a small orifice on the rim of the instrument. The point of light striking the far side of the instrument gave the altitude or tell time.
All those mentioned were the traditional instruments used until well into the second half of the 20th century. After World War II electronic aids to navigation developed very rapidly and, to a great extent, replaced more traditional tools. Electronic speed and depth finders have totally replaced their older counterparts. [[Radar]] has become widespread even in small boats. Some Electronic aids to navigation like [[LORAN]] have already become obsolete themselves and have been replaced by [[GPS]].
== External links == * [http://boatsafe.com/navigation/divide1.htm How to use the dividers] * [http://boatsafe.com/navigation/rules1.htm How to use the parallel rulers] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20121211032356/http://www.marinersmuseum.org/collections/navigating-scientific-instruments Navigational Instruments at The Mariners' Museum]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Navigational Instrument}} [[Category:Navigation]] [[Category:Navigational equipment]]

revision.comment: Reverted edits by [[Special:Contribs/2600:1702:F30:2B90:787E:BE4B:83C4:93BC|2600:1702:F30:2B90:787E:BE4B:83C4:93BC]] ([[User talk:2600:1702:F30:2B90:787E:BE4B:83C4:93BC|talk]]) to last version by CAPTAIN RAJU
revision.text:
{{other uses}} [[File:Map of America by Sebastian Munster.JPG|thumb|upright=1.35|[[Sebastian Münster]]'s map of the New World, first published in 1540]] [[File:Graverat titelblad - Skoklosters slott - 93404.tif|thumb|History of the New World "Historia antipodum oder newe Welt". Matthäus Merian, 1631.]]
The '''New World''' is one of the names used for the majority of [[Earth]]'s [[Western Hemisphere]], specifically the [[Americas]] (including nearby islands such as those of the [[List of Caribbean islands|Caribbean]] and [[Bermuda]]).
The term originated in the early 16th century after [[Voyages of Christopher Columbus|Europeans made landfall]] in what would later be called the Americas in the [[age of discovery]], expanding the geographical horizon of [[Greco-Roman geography|classical geographers]], who had thought of the [[world]] as consisting of [[Africa]], [[Europe]], and [[Asia]], collectively now referred to as the [[Old World]] (a.k.a. [[Afro-Eurasia]]).
The phrase gained prominence after the publication of a pamphlet titled ''Mundus Novus'' attributed to [[Italians|Italian]] explorer [[Amerigo Vespucci]].<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=upkyAQAAMAAJ Mundus Novus: Letter to Lorenzo Pietro Di Medici], by Amerigo Vespucci; translation by George Tyler Northrup, Princeton University Press; 1916.</ref>
The Americas were also referred to as the "fourth part of the world".<ref name="M.H.Davidson 1997 p.417">M.H.Davidson (1997) ''Columbus Then and Now, a life re-examined. Norman: University of Oklahoma Press'', p. 417)</ref>
== Usage == The terms "[[Old World]]" vs. "New World" are meaningful in historical context and for the purpose of distinguishing the world's major [[ecozones]], and to classify plant and animal species that originated therein.
One can speak of the "New World" in a [[history|historical]] context, e.g., when discussing the voyages of [[Christopher Columbus]], the [[Spanish conquest of Yucatán]] and other events of the [[European colonization of the Americas|colonial]] period. For lack of alternatives, the term is also still useful to those discussing issues that concern the Americas and the nearby [[Island#Oceanic islands|oceanic islands]], such as [[Bermuda]] and [[Clipperton Island]], collectively.
The term "New World" is used in a [[biology|biological]] context, when one speaks of Old World ([[Palearctic ecozone|Palearctic]], [[Afrotropic ecozone|Afrotropic]]) and New World species ([[Nearctic ecozone|Nearctic]], [[Neotropic ecozone|Neotropic]]). Biological [[Biological classification|taxonomists]] often attach the "New World" label to groups of species that are found exclusively in the Americas, to distinguish them from their counterparts in the "Old World" (Europe, Africa and Asia), e.g. [[New World monkey]]s, [[New World vulture]]s, [[New World warbler]]s.
The label is also often used in agriculture. Asia, Africa, and Europe share a common agricultural history stemming from the [[Neolithic Revolution]], and the same domesticated plants and animals spread through these three continents thousands of years ago, making them largely indistinct and useful to classify together as "Old World". Common Old World crops (e.g., [[barley]], [[lentil]]s, [[oats]], [[pea]]s, [[rye]], [[wheat]]), and domesticated animals (e.g., [[cattle]], [[chicken]]s, [[goat]]s, [[horse]]s, [[pig]]s, [[sheep]]) did not exist in the Americas until they were introduced by post-[[Voyages of Christopher Columbus|Columbian contact]] in the 1490s (see "[[Columbian Exchange]]"). Conversely, many common [[crops]] were originally domesticated in the Americas before they spread worldwide after Columbian contact, and are still often referred to as "[[New World crops]]"; [[common bean]]s (''phaseolus''), [[maiz]], and [[squash (plant)|squash]] – the "[[Three Sisters (agriculture)|three sisters]]" – as well as the [[avocado]], [[tomato]], and wide varieties of [[capsicum]] ([[bell pepper]], [[chili pepper]], etc.), and the [[turkey (bird)|turkey]] were originally domesticated by [[pre-Columbian]] peoples in [[Mesoamerica]], while agriculturalists in the [[Andean]] region of South America brought forth the [[cassava]], [[peanut]], [[potato]], [[quinoa]] and domesticated animals like the [[alpaca]], [[guinea pig]] and [[llama]]. Other famous New World crops include the [[cashew]], [[cocoa bean|cocoa]], [[rubber]], [[sunflower]], [[tobacco]], and [[vanilla]], and fruits like the [[guava]], [[papaya]] and [[pineapple]]. There are rare instances of overlap, e.g., the [[calabash]] (bottle-gourd), [[cotton]], and [[Yam (vegetable)|yam]], and the dog, are believed to have been domesticated separately in both the [[Old World|Old]] and New World, their early forms possibly brought along by [[Paleo-Indians]] from Asia during the [[last glacial period]].
In [[wine terminology]], "New World" has a different definition. "[[New World wines]]" include not only North American and South American wines, but also those from South Africa, Australia, New Zealand, and all other locations outside the traditional wine-growing regions of Europe, North Africa and the Near East.<ref name="Wine Folly">{{cite web|url=http://winefolly.com/review/new-world-vs-old-world-wine/|title=Real Differences: New World vs Old World Wine |publisher= Wine Folly|date=21 August 2012}}</ref>
==Origin of term==
[[File:Stradanus America.jpg|thumb|Allegory of the New World: [[Amerigo Vespucci]] awakens the sleeping America]] The term "New World" ("Mundus Novus") was first coined by the [[Republic of Florence|Florentine]] explorer [[Amerigo Vespucci]], in a letter written to his friend and former patron [[Lorenzo de' Medici (1463–1503)|Lorenzo di Pier Francesco de' Medici]] in the Spring of 1503, and published (in [[Latin]]) in 1503–04 under the title ''Mundus Novus''. Vespucci's letter contains arguably the first explicit articulation in print of the hypothesis that the lands discovered by European navigators to the west were not the edges of Asia, as asserted by [[Christopher Columbus]], but rather an entirely different continent, a "New World".<ref name="M.H.Davidson 1997 p.417"/>
Vespucci first approached this realization in June 1502, during a famous chance meeting between two different expeditions at the watering stop of "Bezeguiche" (the Bay of [[Dakar]], [[Senegal]]) – his own outgoing expedition, on its way to chart the coast of newly discovered [[Brazil]], and the vanguard ships of the [[2nd Portuguese India Armada (Cabral, 1500)|Second Portuguese India armada]] of [[Pedro Álvares Cabral]], returning home from India. Having already visited the Americas in prior years, Vespucci probably found it difficult to reconcile what he had already seen in the [[West Indies]], with what the returning sailors told him of the [[East Indies]]. Vespucci wrote a preliminary letter to Lorenzo, while anchored at Bezeguiche, which he sent back with the Portuguese fleet – at this point only expressing a certain puzzlement about his conversations.<ref>This preliminary letter from Bezeguiche was not published, but remained in manuscript form. It is reproduced in F.A. de Varnhagen (1865: [https://books.google.com/books?id=R9QOAAAAQAAJ&pg=PA78#v=onepage&q&f=false pp. 78–82]).</ref> Vespucci was finally convinced when he proceeded on his mapping expedition through 1501–02, covering the huge stretch of coast of eastern Brazil. After returning from Brazil, in the Spring of 1503, Amerigo Vespucci composed the ''Mundus Novus'' letter in Lisbon to Lorenzo in Florence, with its famous opening paragraph:<ref>English translation of ''Mundus Novus'' as found in Markham (1894: [https://books.google.com/books?id=8wAuAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA42#v=onepage&q&f=false pp. 42–52])</ref>
{{quote|In passed days I wrote very fully to you of my return from new countries, which have been found and explored with the ships, at the cost and by the command of this Most Serene King of Portugal; and it is lawful to call it a new world, because none of these countries were known to our ancestors and all who hear about them they will be entirely new. For the opinion of the ancients was, that the greater part of the world beyond the equinoctial line to the south was not land, but only sea, which they have called the Atlantic; and even if they have affirmed that any continent is there, they have given many reasons for denying it is inhabited. But this opinion is false, and entirely opposed to the truth. My last voyage has proved it, for I have found a continent in that southern part; full of animals and more populous than our Europe, or Asia, or Africa, and even more temperate and pleasant than any other region known to us.|}}
Vespucci's letter was a publishing sensation in Europe, immediately (and repeatedly) reprinted in several other countries.<ref>Varnhagen, ''Amerígo Vespucci'' (1865: [https://books.google.com/books?id=R9QOAAAAQAAJ&pg=PA13#v=onepage&q&f=false pp. 13–26]) provides side-by-side reproductions of both the 1503 Latin version ''Mundus Novus'', and the 1507 Italian re-translation "El Nuovo Mondo de Lengue Spagnole interpretato in Idioma Ro. Libro Quinto" (from ''Paesi Nuovamente retrovati''). The Latin version of ''Mundus Novus'' was reprinted many times (see Varnhagen, 1865: [https://books.google.com/books?id=R9QOAAAAQAAJ&pg=PA9#v=onepage&q&f=false p. 9] for a list of early reprints).</ref>
=== Prior usage ===
While Amerigo Vespucci is usually credited for coming up with the term "New World" (''Mundus Novus'') for the Americas in his 1503 letter, certainly giving it its popular cachet, similar terms had nonetheless been used and applied before him.
The [[Republic of Venice|Venetian]] explorer [[Alvise Cadamosto]] had used the term "un altro mundo" ("another world") to refer to [[sub-Saharan Africa]], which he explored in 1455 and 1456 on behalf of the Portuguese.<ref>Cadamosto ''Navigationi'', c. 1470, as reprinted in Giovanni Ramusio (1554: [https://books.google.com/books?id=iZ5TZHXOnYcC&pg=RA2-PA106-IA3#v=onepage&q&f=false p. 106]). See also M. Zamora ''Reading Columbus'', (1993: p. 121)</ref> However, this was merely a literary flourish, not a suggestion of a new "fourth" part of the world. Cadamosto was quite aware sub-Saharan Africa was firmly part of the African continent.
The [[Italy|Italian]]-born Spanish chronicler [[Peter Martyr d'Anghiera]] often shares credit with Vespucci for designating the Americas as a new world.<ref>{{cite book| last= de Madariaga | first= Salvador | authorlink= Salvador de Madariaga | year=1952 | publisher= Editorial Hermes | location= Mexico | edition= 5th | title= Vida del muy magnífico señor Don Cristóbal Colón | page= 363 | quote= "nuevo mundo", [...] designación que Pedro Mártyr será el primero en usar | language= Spanish}}</ref> Peter Martyr used the term ''Orbe Novo'' (literally, "New Globe", but often translated as "New World") in the title of his history of the discovery of the Americas as a whole, which began to appear in 1511 (cosmologically, "orbis" as used here refers to the whole hemisphere, while "mundus" refers to the land within it).<ref>J.Z. Smith, ''Relating Religion'', Chicago (2004: p. 268)</ref> Peter Martyr had been writing and circulating private letters commenting on Columbus's discoveries since 1493 and, from the start, doubted Columbus's claims to have reached East Asia ("the Indies"), and consequently came up with alternative names to refer to them.<ref>E.G. Bourne ''Spain in America, 1450–580'' New York: Harper (1904: p. 30)</ref> Only a few weeks after Columbus's return from his first voyage, Peter Martyr wrote letters referring to Columbus's discovered lands as the "western antipodes" ("antipodibus occiduis", letter of May 14, 1493),<ref>Peter Martyr, ''Opus Epistolarum'' (Letter 130 [https://books.google.com/books?id=pmFEAAAAcAAJ&pg=PA72#v=onepage&q&f=false p. 72])</ref> the "new hemisphere of the earth" ("novo terrarum hemisphaerio", September 13, 1493),<ref>Peter Martyr, ''Opus Epistolarum'', Letter 133, [https://books.google.com/books?id=pmFEAAAAcAAJ&pg=PA73#v=onepage&q&f=false p. 73]</ref> and in a letter dated November 1, 1493, refers to Columbus as the "discoverer of the new globe" ("Colonus ille novi orbis repertor").<ref>Peter Martyr, ''Opus Epistolarum'' (Letter 138, [https://books.google.com/books?id=pmFEAAAAcAAJ&pg=PA76#v=onepage&q&f=false p. 76])</ref> A year later (October 20, 1494), Peter Martyr again refers to the marvels of the New Globe ("Novo Orbe") and the "Western hemisphere."("ab occidente hemisphero").<ref>Peter Martyr ''Opus Epistolarum'', Letter 156 [https://books.google.com/books?id=pmFEAAAAcAAJ&pg=PA88#v=onepage&q&f=false p. 88]</ref>
[[Christopher Columbus]] touched the continent of South America in his 1498 [[Voyages of Christopher Columbus#Third voyage|third voyage]]. In his own 1499 letter to the [[Catholic Monarchs]] of Spain, reporting the results of his third voyage, Columbus relates how the massive waters of the [[Orinoco]] delta rushing into the [[Gulf of Paria]] implied that a previously unknown continent must lie behind it.<ref>"if the river mentioned does not proceed from the terrestrial paradise, it comes from an immense tract of land situated in the south, of which no knowledge has been hitherto obtained" (Columbus 1499 letter on the third voyage, as reproduced in R.H. Major, ''Select Letters of Christopher Columbus'', 1870: [https://books.google.com/books?id=zFjUAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA147#v=onepage&q&f=false p. 147])</ref> However, bowing to the classical tripartite division of the world, Columbus discards that hypothesis and proposes instead that the South American landmass is not a "fourth" continent, but rather the [[terrestrial paradise]] of Biblical tradition, not a previously unknown "new" part of the world, but a land already "known" (but location undiscovered) by [[Christendom]].<ref>J.Z. Smith, ''Relating Religion'', Chicago (2004: pp. 266–67)</ref> In another letter (to the nurse of Prince John, written 1500), Columbus refers to having reached a "new heavens and world" ("nuevo cielo e mundo")<ref>Columbus 1500 letter to the nurse (in Major, 1870: [https://books.google.com/books?id=zFjUAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA154#v=onepage&q&f=false p. 154])</ref> and that he had placed "another world" ("otro mundo") under the dominion of the Kings of Spain.<ref>Columbus's 1500 letter to the nurse(Major, 1870: [https://books.google.com/books?id=zFjUAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA170#v=onepage&q&f=false p. 170])</ref>
=== Acceptance === The Vespucci passage above applied the "New World" label to merely the continental landmass of [[South America]].<ref>F.A. Ober ''Amerigo Vespucci'' New York: Harper (1907: pp. 239, 244)</ref> At the time, most of the continent of [[North America]] was not yet discovered, and Vespucci's comments did not eliminate the possibility that the islands of the [[Antilles]] discovered earlier by [[Christopher Columbus]] might still be the eastern edges of Asia, as Columbus continued to insist down to his dying day.<ref>S.E. Morison ''The European Discovery of America, v.2: The southern voyages, 1492–1616''.(1974: pp. 265–66).</ref> A critical step in the transition was the conference of navigators (''Junta de Navegantes'') assembled by the Spanish monarchs at [[Toro, Zamora|Toro]] in 1505, and continued at [[Burgos]] in 1508, to digest all existing information about the Indies, come to an agreement on what had really been discovered, and set out the future goals of Spanish exploration. Amerigo Vespucci attended both conferences, and seems to have had an outsized influence on them – Vespucci ended up being appointed the first ''piloto mayor'', the chief of navigation of Spain, at Burgos.<ref>For an account of Vespucci at Toro and Burgos, see Navarette ''Colección de los viages y descubrimientos que hicieron por mar los españoles desde fines del siglo XV''(1829: v.iii, [https://books.google.com/books?id=ESYW_1DUELoC&pg=PA320#v=onepage&q&f=false pp. 320–23])</ref> Although the proceedings of the Toro-Burgos conferences are missing, it is almost certain that Vespucci articulated his recent "New World" thesis to his fellow navigators there. It was during these conferences when Spanish officials seem to have finally accepted that the Antilles and the known stretch of Central America were definitely ''not'' the Indies they had originally sought, and Columbus had insisted they were, and set out the new goal for Spanish explorers: to find a sea passage or [[strait]] through the Americas which would permit them to sail to Asia proper.<ref>C.O. Sauer ''The Early Spanish Main''. Cambridge (1966: pp. 166–67)</ref> In English usage the term "New World" was problematic and only accepted relatively late.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Sobecki|first1=Sebastian|title=New World Discovery|journal=Oxford Handbooks Online|date=2015|doi=10.1093/oxfordhb/9780199935338.001.0001|url=http://www.oxfordhandbooks.com/view/10.1093/oxfordhb/9780199935338.001.0001/oxfordhb-9780199935338-e-141|accessdate=2 June 2016|doi-broken-date=2018-05-19}}</ref>
=== Cartographic representation ===
[[File:Map Diego Ribero 1529.jpg|thumb|The World Map by [[Diogo Ribeiro]] (1529) labels the [[Americas]] as ''MUNDUS NOVUS''. It traces most of South America and the east coast of North America.]] While it became generally accepted after Vespucci that Columbus's discoveries were not Asia but a "New World", the geographic relationship between the two continents was still unclear.<ref name = parry>J.H. Parry, ''The Discovery of the Sea'' (1974: p. 227)</ref> That there must be a large ocean between Asia and the Americas was implied by the known existence of vast continuous sea along the coasts of [[East Asia]]. Given the size of the Earth as calculated by [[Eratosthenes]] this left a large space between Asia and the newly discovered lands.
Even prior to Vespucci, several maps, e.g. the [[Cantino planisphere]] of 1502 and the [[Canerio map]] of 1504, placed a large open ocean between China on the east side of the map, and the inchoate largely water-surrounded North American and South American discoveries on the western side of map. However, out of uncertainty, they depicted a finger of the Asian land mass stretching across the top to the eastern edge of the map, suggesting it carried over into the western hemisphere (e.g. the Cantino Planisphere denotes [[Greenland]] as "Punta d'Asia" – "edge of Asia"). Some maps, e.g. the 1506 [[Contarini–Rosselli map]] and the 1508 [[Johannes Ruysch]] map, bowing to Ptolemaic authority and Columbus's assertions, have the northern Asian landmass stretching well into the western hemisphere and merging with known North America (Labrador, Newfoundland, etc.). These maps place the island of Japan near Cuba and leave the South American continent – Vespucci's "New World" proper – detached and floating below by itself.<ref name = parry/> The [[Waldseemüller map]] of 1507, which accompanied the famous ''[[Cosmographiae Introductio]]'' volume (which includes reprints of Vespucci's letters) comes closest to modernity by placing a completely open sea (with no stretching land fingers) between Asia on the eastern side and the New World (being represented two times in the same map in a different way: with and without a sea passage in the middle of what is now named Central America) on the western side – which (on what is now named South America) that same map famously labels simply "''[[Naming of America|America]]''". However, [[Martin Waldseemüller]]'s map of 1516 retreats considerably from his earlier map and back to classical authority, with the Asian land mass merging into North America (which he now calls ''Terra de Cuba Asie partis''), and quietly drops the "America" label from South America, calling it merely ''[[Terra incognita|Terra Incognita]]''.<ref name = parry/>
The western coast of the New World – the [[Pacific Ocean]] – was only discovered in 1513 by [[Vasco Núñez de Balboa]]. But it would take a few more years – [[Ferdinand Magellan]]'s voyage of 1519–22 – to determine that the Pacific definitely formed a single large body of water separating Asia from the Americas. It would be several more years before the Pacific Coast of North America was mapped, dispelling lingering doubts. Until the discovery of the [[Bering Strait]]s in the 17th century, there was no absolute confirmation that Asia and North America were not connected, and some European maps of the 16th century still continued to hopefully depict North America connected by a land bridge to Asia (e.g. the 1533 [[Johannes Schöner globe]]).<ref name = parry/>
In 1524, the term was used by [[Giovanni da Verrazzano]] in a record of his voyage that year along the Atlantic coast of [[North America]], land that is now part of the [[United States]] and [[Canada]].<ref>Verrazzano, Giovanni da (1524).[http://bc.barnard.columbia.edu/~lgordis/earlyAC/documents/verrazan.htm "The Written Record of the Voyage of 1524 of Giovanni da Verrazzano as recorded in a letter to Francis I, King of France, July 8th, 1524"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060908085440/http://bc.barnard.columbia.edu/~lgordis/earlyAC/documents/verrazan.htm |date=2006-09-08 }}. Citing: Wroth, Lawrence C., ed. (1970). ''The Voyages of Giovanni da Verrazzano, 1524–1528''. Yale, pp. 133–43. Citing: a translation by Susan Tarrow of the ''[[Cèllere Codex]]''.</ref>
==See also== *[[European colonization of the Americas]] *[[Prehistoric migration and settlement of the Americas from Asia|Settlement of the Americas]] {{Clear}}
==References== {{Reflist}}

revision.text:
The '''Order of Magellan''' is an honor bestowed on distinguished individuals who have [[circumnavigation|circumnavigated]] the earth and who, to the course of their career, have contributed to the world of science or the environment or future progress through peace and understanding. Among the pantheon of winners of this award are [[Douglas MacArthur]], [[philanthropist]] and [[mountaineer]] Sir [[Edmund Hillary]], [[ethnographer]] and [[adventurer]] [[Thor Heyerdahl]], Dr. [[William B. Walsh|William Walsh]], who started Project Hope, [[oceanographer]] and underwater archaeologist Dr. [[Robert Ballard]], oceanographer [[Jacques-Yves Cousteau]], and astronaut and United States Senator [[John Glenn]]. The Magellan Award is the highest award bestowed by the Circumnavigators Club,<ref>[http://www.circumnavigators.org/magellan/past.php The Circumnavigators Club<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090830193139/http://www.circumnavigators.org/magellan/past.php |date=2009-08-30 }}</ref> founded in 1902. The honor is named after the [[Portuguese people|Portuguese]] born explorer, [[Ferdinand Magellan]], who is widely known as the first captain to sail around the world—though he didn't complete the circumnavigation as he died during the voyage in the Philippines, that being the Spanish navigator [[Juan Sebastián Elcano]], who took over command of the expedition after Magellan's death, and completed the trip.
==References== <references />
==External links== * [http://www.history.navy.mil/faqs/faq92-3.htm U.S. Naval History and Heritage Command] * [http://circumnavigators.org/ Circumnavigators Club official site]
[[Category:Awards and decorations of the United States Navy]] [[Category:Navigation]]

page.title: Permanent European Conference for the Study of the Rural Landscape

revision.comment: /* Conferences */
revision.text:
{{primarysources|date=May 2008}}
The '''Permanent European Conference for the Study of the Rural Landscape (PECSRL)''' is an international network of [[landscape]] researchers whose interest focus on the past, present and future of European landscapes, and serves as an international platform for new initiatives, meetings and publications about European rural landscapes. It meets every two years in a different European country for lectures, discussions, working groups and landscape excursions. It has several working groups that focus on actual problems in European landscape management and landscape research. The unifying concept of PECSRL is the past, present and future of European landscapes, relating to landscape research as well as landscape policy and landscape management.
==Objectives== The objectives of PECSRL are: * to facilitate personal contacts and information exchange between European landscape researchers; * to improve interdisciplinary cooperation between landscape researchers from various scientific and human landscape disciplines; * to improve cooperation between landscape researchers and landscape managers; * to function as a platform for new initiatives in European landscape research and landscape management.
==History and scope== The Permanent European Conference for the Study of the Rural Landscape is one of the most stable European networks of landscape researchers. It was established in 1957 at an inaugural conference held in Nancy, France. Initially, it consisted mainly of [[Historical geography|(historical)]] [[geography|geographers]], but during the last few decades its membership has diversified to include ecologists, social scientists, rural planners, landscape architects, historians, archaeologists, landscape managers, as well as other scholars and practitioners interested in European landscapes. Members undertake both fundamental and applied research on all aspects of the rural landscape or have a position in landscape management or heritage management. PECSRL covers Pan-Europe which means that it connects researchers from Northern, Eastern, Southern, Central and Western Europe. All together more than thirty European countries take part in PECSRL.
==Conferences== * 28th Session: [https://pecsrl2018.sciencesconf.org/ "European Landscapes for Quality of Life?"], 2018, Clermont-Ferrand and Mende (France) * 27th Session: [http://www.pecsrl2016.com/ "Mountains, uplands, lowlands. European landscapes from an altitudinal perspective"], 2016, Innsbruck and Seefeld (Austria) * 26th Session: [http://www.pecsrl2014.com/ "Unraveling the Logics of Landscape"], 2014, Gothenburg and Mariestad (Sweden) * 25th Session: [http://www.pecsrl2012.com/ "Reflection on landscape change: the European perspective"], 2012, Leeuwarden and Terschelling (the Netherlands) * 24th Session: [http://www.lu.lv/eng/news/t/1305/ "Living in Landscapes: Knowledge, Practice, Imagination"], 2010, Riga and Liepaja (Latvia) * 23rd Session: [https://web.archive.org/web/20080311224409/http://tercud.ulusofona.pt/PECSRL2008.htm "Landscapes, identities and development"], 2008, Lisbon and Óbidos (Portugal) * 22nd Session: "European rural future“: Landscape as an interface", 2006, Berlin and Schloss Hubertusstock (Germany) * 21st Session: "One region, many stories - Mediterranean landscapes in a changing Europe", 2004, Limnos and Lesvos (Greece) * 20th Session: "Rural landscapes: past processes - future strategies", 2002, Tartu and Otepää (Estonia) * 19th Session: "European landscapes, from mountain to sea", 2000, London and Aberystwyth (United Kingdom) * 18th Session: "Shaping the land", 1998, Røros and Trondheim (Norway) * 17th Session, 1996, Dublin (Ireland) * 16th Session: "Rural landscape between State and Local Communities", 1994, Torino (Italy) * 15th Session: "L'avenir des paysages ruraix européens", 1992, Lyon (France) * 14th Session: "The transformation of the European rural landscape", 1990, Baarn and Ghent (The Netherlands / Belgium) * 13th Session, 1987, Stockholm (Sweden) * 12th Session, 1985, Rastede and Hagen (Federal Republic of Germany) * 11th Session, 1981, Durham and Cambridge (England) * 10th Session, 1979, Roskilde (Denmark) * 9th Session, 1977, Rennes and Quimper (France) * 8th Session, 1975, Warsaw (Poland) * 7th Session, 1973, Perugia (Italy) * 6th Session, 1971, Belfast (Northern Ireland) * 5th Session, 1969, Liège (Belgium) * 4th Session, 1966, Würzburg (Federal Republic of Germany) * 3rd Session, 1964, Birmingham (England) * 2nd Session, 1960, Vadstena (Sweden) * 1st Session, 1957, Nancy (France)
==See also== *[[Landscape]] *[[Cultural landscape]] *[[Landscape planning]] *[[European Landscape Convention]]
==Further reading== *Baker, Alan R.H. (1988) Historical Geography and the Study of the European Rural Landscape. ''Geografiska Annaler'' 70B (1) 5-16. *Helmfrid, Staffan (2004) The Permanent European Conference and the Study of the Rural Landscape. In Palang, Hannes (red.) (2004). ''European rural landscapes: persistence and change in a globalising environment''. Boston: Kluwer Academic Publishers, p. 467 -
==External links== * [http://www.pecsrl.org/ Permanent European Conference for the Study of the Rural Landscape (PECSRL)]

revision.text:
{{distinguish|Prime meridian|Central meridian (disambiguation){{!}}Central meridian}} A '''principal meridian''' is a [[meridian (geography)|meridian]] used for survey control in a large region. ==Canada== The [[Dominion Land Survey]] of [[Western Canada]] took its origin at the First (or Principal) Meridian, located at 97°27′28.41″ west of [[Prime Meridian|Greenwich]], just west of [[Winnipeg, Manitoba]]. This line is exactly ten miles west of the Red River at the Canada-United States border. Six other meridians were designated at four-degree intervals westward, with the seventh located in British Columbia; the second and fourth meridians form the general eastern border and the western border of [[Saskatchewan]]. ==United States== [[File:Meridians-baselines.png|thumb|300px|right|This [[Bureau of Land Management|BLM]] map depicts the principal meridians and [[baseline (surveying)|baselines]] used for surveying states (colored) in the PLSS.]] In the [[United States]] [[Public Land Survey System]], a principal meridian is the principal north-south line used for survey control in a large region, and which divides townships between east and west. The meridian meets its corresponding [[baseline (surveying)|baseline]] at the point of origin, or [[initial point]], for the land survey. For example, the [[Mount Diablo Meridian]], used for surveys in California and Nevada, runs north-south through the summit of [[Mount Diablo State Park|Mount Diablo]]. Often, meridians are marked with roads, such as the Meridian Avenue in [[San Jose, California]], Meridian Road in [[Vacaville, California]], both on the [[Mount Diablo Meridian]], Meridian Road in [[Wichita, Kansas]] on the Sixth Principal Meridian, and Meridian Avenue in several western Washington counties generally following the Willamette Meridian. Baseline Road or Base Line Street extends for about 40 miles from [[Highland, California]] east of San Bernardino to [[La Verne, California]] where it meets Foothill Boulevard. == See also == *[[Cardo]] *[[Baseline (surveying)]] *[[List of principal and guide meridians and base lines of the United States]] ==External links== *[http://www.pmproject.org/ The Principal Meridian Project (US)] *[http://www.blm.gov/cadastral/Manual/pdffiles/histrect.pdf History of the Rectangular Survey System] Note: this is a large file, approximately 46MB. Searchable PDF prepared by the author, C. A. White. *[https://web.archive.org/web/20081011172949/http://www.blm.gov/wo/st/en/prog/more/cadastralsurvey/tools.html Resources page of the U.S. Department of the Interior, Bureau of Land Management]
[[Category:Surveying]] [[Category:Lines of longitude]] [[Category:Meridians and base lines of the United States| ]] {{Cartography-stub}} {{Geo-term-stub}}

revision.text:
{{redirect|Remoteness (location)|other remote locations|Extreme points of Earth#Remoteness}}
In Canada, the statistical designation '''remote and isolated community''' refers to a settlement that is either a long distance from larger settlements or lacks transportation links that are typical in more populated areas.
In responding to the [[avian flu outbreak of 2009]], a Canadian government body (the Remote and Isolated Task Group [RITG] of the Public Health Network H1N1 Task Force) published the following [[working definitions]]: {{quote|Remote: describes a geographical area where a community is located over 350 km from the nearest service centre having year-round road access.
''Isolated'', by the Canadian government definition, means a geographical area that has scheduled flights and good telephone services, but is without year-round road access. Note that not all homes in a community have phones, and that flights may be cancelled or delayed due to weather.|RITG<ref name="phac-aspc.gc.ca">http://www.phac-aspc.gc.ca/alert-alerte/h1n1/guidance_lignesdirectrices/cdricp-cdeicp-eng.php</ref>}} In the above quote, the definition of isolated is borrowed from [[Indian and Northern Affairs Canada]] (INAC) and the definition of remote is borrowed from [[Health Canada]].<ref name="phac-aspc.gc.ca">http://www.phac-aspc.gc.ca/alert-alerte/h1n1/guidance_lignesdirectrices/cdricp-cdeicp-eng.php</ref>
Canada also has ''fly-in communities'' that lack road, rail, or water connections and rely entirely on [[bush aviation]]. Other remote communities lack road and rail but have water access, such as the [[Newfoundland outport]]s, and those that have road access part of the year on [[ice roads]], or can only be reached by [[gravel road]]. One academic measure of remoteness used in Canada is [[nordicity]], i.e. "northerliness".
== Healthcare in remote and isolated communities == {{see also|Rural health}} In Canada, there were 76 [[nursing stations]] and over 195 [[health centres]] servicing remote communities in [[Northern Canada]] or on [[Indian reserves]] in the south. In about facilities, [[registered nurses]] are employed by [[Health Canada]], a ministry of the [[government of Canada]]. In the other communities, nurses are employed by the [[First Nations government|Band Council]].<ref>http://www.hc-sc.gc.ca/fniah-spnia/services/nurs-infirm/index-eng.php</ref>
== Policing in remote and isolated communities == Policing in remote areas presents many challenges, most obviously logistical, but also social and even psychological.
The [[Royal Canadian Mounted Police]] had 268 "isolated posts" in 2009. Isolated posts are defined by the [[Treasury Board of Canada]] as communities that face "unique challenges" related to small populations, harsh climates, and/or limited access by commercial transportation or all-weather roads.<ref name="rcmp-grc.gc.ca">http://www.rcmp-grc.gc.ca/gazette/vol71n1/vol71n5-eng.pdf</ref> All posts located in Canada's [[Northern Canada|three northern territories]] are considered isolated as well as many in the ten provinces. Many of these posts are "fly-in only"; the police force has its own RCMP Air Services, which does everything from ferry prisoners to court to bring in new computers to offices. In 2009, in the territory of [[Nunavut]] there were 25 detachments, all fly-in (no roads), and only one RCMP airplane.<ref name="rcmp-grc.gc.ca"/>
==See also== *[[Extreme points of Canadian provinces]] *[[Extreme communities of Canada]] *[[Nordicity]]
== References == <references/>
[[Category:Geography terminology]] [[Category:Types of populated places]] [[Category:Designated places in Canada]] [[Category:Geography of Canada]] [[Category:Northern Canada]] [[Category:Demographics of Canada]]
